abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for the Second National
            Agricultural Services Development Project for Burkina Faso
            are as follows: Project outcome is unsatisfactory;
            sustainability is unlikely; institutional development impact
            is modest; Bank performance is unsatisfactory; and Borrower
            performance is unsatisfactory. Among the lessons cited were:
            1) Achieving an integrated extension service requires a
            unique institutional setting particularly in an environment
            where coordination and communication are ineffective. The
            split of the Ministry of Agriculture into two ministries
            made the implementation of this approach impossible. Project
            implementation proved, in the livestock sector, that the
            extension service delivery should have relied more on
            livestock specialists for pastoralist and semi-intensive
            production systems, and on private veterinarians for animal
            health. 2) Monitoring and evaluation activity should be put
            at the forefront of project design and implementation. Two
            ways to achieve that in this case are to: (a) make every
            effort to effectively involve all national institutions
            responsible for data collection and management, or (b)
            create a Network of Impact Studies integrating the
            institutions in charge of data collection and management
            under the auspices of a strong national research
            institution. 3) For service delivery to be efficient and
            sustained, a holistic approach should be pursued based on:
            (a) a more professionalized and decentralized service
            delivery accountable to farmers; (b) improved market and
            credit access to create incentives to increase productivity
            and new technology adoption; (c) promoting small rural
            agro-industries in which the private sector, particularly
            professional organizations, have a key role to play; and (d)
            a sustainable financial mechanism to fund extension and
            research service delivery. 4) Empowering farmers and
            communities is a long process whose outcome cannot be
            achieved overnight. 5) Privatizing service delivery happened
            to be more complex than anticipated. This requires an
            enabling environment, a strong political will, a critical
            mass of private actors and more experienced professional
            organizations supported by a strong capacity building
            program to foster public-private partnership.
